sourceDesc.p:
Play details
All's well, that ends well. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1623. Date first performed: 1603-1604.
Electronic text obtained Oxford, 1991, checked against Norton facsimile First Folio edition edited by Charlton Hinman

div2.head: Actus primus. Scoena Prima.
div2.stage:
Enter yong Bertram Count of Rossillion, his Mother, and
Helena, Lord Lafew, all in blacke.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p:
In delivering my son from me, I bury a second
husband.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
And I in going Madam, weep over my
fathers death anew; but I must attend his majesties
command, to whom I am now in Ward, evermore
in subjection.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
You shall find of the King a husband Madam,
you sir a father. He that so generally is at all times good,
must of necessity hold his virtue to you, whose worthiness
would stir it up where it wanted rather than lack
it where there is such abundance.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What hope is there of his Majesties amendment?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
He hath abandoned his Physicians Madam, under
whose practises he hath persecuted time with hope,
and finds no other advantage in the process, but only the loosing of hope by time.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p:
This young Gentlewoman had a father, O that
had, how sad a passage it is, whose skill was almost as
great as his honesty, had it stretched so far, would have
made nature immortal, and death should have play for
lack of work. Would for the Kings sake he were living,
I think it would be the death of the Kings disease.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: How called you the man you speak of Madam?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: He was famous sir in his profession, and it was
his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
He was excellent indeed Madam, the King very
lately spoke of him admiringly, and mourningly: he
was skilful enough to have lived still, if knowledge could
be set up against mortality.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
What is it (my good Lord) the King languishes
of?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: A Fistula my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I heard not of it before.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I would it were not notorious. Was this Gentlewoman
the Daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p:
His sole child my Lord, and bequeathed to my
overlooking. I have those hopes of her good, that her
education promises her dispositions she inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer: for where an unclean mind carries
virtuous qualities, there commendations go with
pity, they are virtues and traitors too: in her they are
the better for their simpleness; she derives her honesty,
and achieves her goodness.

sp.speaker: Lafew.
sp.p:
Your commendations Madam get from her
tears.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p:
It is the best brine a Maiden can season her praise
in. The remembrance of her father never approaches her
heart, but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all livelihood
from her cheek. No more of this Helena, go to, no
more lest it be rather thought you affect a sorrow, than
to have ~~

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
excessive grief the enemy to the living.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p:
If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess
makes it soon mortal.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Madam I desire your holy wishes.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: How understand we that?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Be thou blessed Bertrame, and succeed thy father
In manners as in shape: thy blood and virtue
Contend for Empire in thee, and thy goodness
Share with thy birth-right. Love all, trust a few,
Do wrong to none: be able for thine enemy
Rather in power than use: and keep thy friend
Under thy own life's key. Be checked for silence,
But never taxed for speech. What heaven more will,
That thee may furnish, and my prayers pluck down,
Fall on thy head. Farewell my Lord,
It is an unseasoned Courtier, good my Lord
Advise him.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: He cannot want the best
That shall attend his love.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Heaven bless him: Farewell Bertram.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
The best wishes that can be forged in your thoughts
be servants to you: be comfortable to my mother, your
Mistress, and make much of her.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Farewell pretty Lady, you must hold the credit
of your father.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: O were that all, I think not on my father,
And these great tears grace his remembrance more
Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
I have forgot him. My imagination
Carries no favour in it but Bertrams.
I am undone, there is no living, none,
If Bertram be away. It were all one,
That I should love a bright particular star,
And think to wed it, he is so above me
In his bright radiance and collateral light,
Must I be comforted, not in his sphere;
The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
The hind that would be mated by the Lion
Must die for love. It was pretty, though a plague
To see him every hour to sit and draw
His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls
In our hearts table: heart too capable
Of every line and trick of his sweet favour.
But now he is gone, and my idolatrous fancy
Must sanctify his Relics. Who comes here?
One that goes with him: I love him for his sake,
And yet I know him a notorious Liar,
Think him a great way fool, solely a coward,
Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him,
That they take place, when Virtues steely bones
Looks bleak in the cold wind: withal, full oft we see
Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Save you fair Queen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And you Monarch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And no.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Are you meditating on virginity?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Aye: you have some stain of soldier in you: Let
me ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity,
how may we barracado it against him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Keep him out.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
But he assails, and our virginity though valiant,
in the defence yet is weak: unfold to us some warlike
resistance.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
There is none: Man setting down before you,
will undermine you, and blow you up.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Bless our poor Virginity from underminers
and blowers up. Is there no Military policy how Virgins
might blow up men?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Virginity being blown down, Man will
quicklier be blown up: marry in blowing him down
again, with the breach yourselves made, you lose your
City. It is not politic, in the Common-wealth of
Nature, to preserve virginity. Loss of Virginity, is
rational increase, and there was never Virgin go, till
virginity was first lost. That you were made of, is metal
to make Virgins. Virginity, by being once lost,
may be ten times found: by being ever kept, it is ever
lost: it is too cold a companion: Away with it.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I will stand for it a little, though therefore I die a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
There is little can be said in it, it is against the
rule of Nature. To speak on the part of virginity, is
to accuse your Mothers; which is most infallible disobedience. He that hangs himself is a Virgin: Virginity
murthers itself, and should be buried in highways out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate Offendress against Nature. Virginity breeds mites, much like a Cheese, consumes itself to the very pairing, and so
dies with feeding his own stomach. Besides, Virginity
is peevish, proud, idle, made of self-love, which
is the most inhibited sin in the Cannon. Keep it not,
you cannot choose but lose by it. Out with it: within
ten year it will make itself two, which is a goodly increase,
and the principal itself not much the worse.
Away with it.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: How might one do sir, to lose it to her own liking?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Let me see. Marry ill, to like him that never
it likes. It is a commodity will lose the gloss with lying:
The longer kept, the less worth: Off with it while it is
vendible. Answer the time of request, Virginity like
an old Courtier, wears her cap out of fashion, richly
suited, but unsuitable, just like the brooch and the tooth-pick,
which were not now: your Date is better in your
Pie and your Porridge, than in your cheek: and your
virginity, your old virginity, is like one of our French
withered pears, it looks ill, it eats drily, marry it is a
withered pear: it was formerly better, marry yet it is a
withered pear: Will you anything with it?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Not my virginity yet:
There shall your Master have a thousand loves,
A Mother, and a Mistress, and a friend,
A Phoenix, Captain, and an enemy,
A guide, a Goddess, and a Sovereign,
A Counsellor, a Traitoress, and a Dear:
His humble ambition, proud humility:
His jarring, concord: and his discord, dulcet:
His faith, his sweet disaster: with a world
Of pretty fond adoptious christendoms
That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he:
I know not what he shall, God send him well,
The Court is a learning place, and he is one.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What one i'faith?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: That I wish well, it is pity.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What is pity?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That wishing well had not a body in it,
Which might be felt, that we the poorer born,
Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,
Might with effects of them follow our friends,
And show what we alone must think, which never
Returns us thanks.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Monsieur Parrolles,
My Lord calls for you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Little Hellen farewell, if I can remember thee, I
will think of thee at Court.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a
charitable star.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Under Mars I.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I especially think, under Mars.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why under Mars?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: The wars hath so kept you under, that you must needs be born under Mars.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: When he was predominant.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: When he was retrograde I think rather.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: You go so much backward when you fight.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That is for advantage.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: So is running away,
When fear proposes the safety:
sp.p:
But the composition that your valour and fear makes
in you, is a virtue of a good wing, and I like the
wear well.

sp.speaker: Paroll.
sp.p:
I am so full of businesses, I cannot answer
thee acutely: I will return perfect Courtier, in the
which my instruction shall serve to naturalise thee, so
thou wilt be capable of a Courtiers council, and understand
what advice shall thrust upon thee, else thou
diest in thine unthankfulness, and thine ignorance makes
thee away, farewell: When thou hast leisure, say thy
prayers: when thou hast none, remember thy Friends:
Get thee a good husband, and use him as he uses thee:
So farewell.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie,
Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated sky
Gives us free scope, only doth backward pull
Our slow designs, when we ourselves are dull.
What power is it, which mounts my love so high,
That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
The mightiest space in fortune, Nature brings
To join like, likes; and kiss like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their pains in sense, and do suppose
What hath been, cannot be. Whoever strove
To show her merit, that did miss her love?
(The Kings disease) my project may deceive me,
But my intents are fixed, and will not leave me.

div2.stage:
Flourish Cornets.
Enter the King of France with Letters, and
diuers Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Florentines and Senoys are by the ears,
Have fought with equal fortune, and continue
A braving war.

sp.speaker: Lo. G.
sp.l: So it is reported sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay it is most credible, we here receive it,
A certainty vouched from our Cousin Austria,
With caution, that the Florentine will move us
For speedy aid: wherein our dearest friend
Prejudicates the business, and would seem
To have us make denial.

sp.speaker: Lo. G.
sp.l: His love and wisdom
Approved so to your Majesty, may plead
For amplest credence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He hath armed our answer,
And Florence is denied before he comes:
Yet for our Gentlemen that mean to see
The Tuscan service, freely have they leave
To stand on either part.

sp.speaker: 2.Lo. E.
sp.l: It well may serve
A nursery to our Gentry, who are sick
For breathing, and exploit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What is he comes here.

sp.speaker: 1.Lor.G.
sp.l: It is the Count Rosignoll my good Lord,
Young Bertram.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Youth, thou bearest thy Fathers face,
Frank Nature rather curious than in haste
Hath well composed thee: Thy Fathers moral parts
Mayst thou inherit too: Welcome to Paris.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My thanks and duty are your Majesties.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I would I had that corporal soundness now,
As when thy father, and myself., in friendship
First tried our soldiership: he did look far.
Into the service of the time, and was
Discipled of the bravest. He lasted long,
But on us both did haggish Age steal on,
And wore us out of act: It much repairs me
To talk of your good father; in his youth
He had the wit, which I can well observe
Today in our young Lords: but they may jest
Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
Ere they can hide their levity in honour:
So like a Courtier, contempt nor bitterness
Were in his pride, or sharpness; if they were,
His equal had awaked them, and his honour
Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him speak: and at this time
His tongue obeyed his hand. Who were below him,
He used as creatures of another place,
And bowed his eminent top to their low ranks,
Making them proud of his humility,
In their poor praise he humbled: Such a man
Might be a copy to these younger times;
Which followed well, would demonstrate them now
But goers backward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: His good remembrance sir
Lies richer in your thoughts, than on his tomb:
So in approof lives not his Epitaph,
As in your royal speech.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Would I were with him he would always say,
(Methinks. I hear him now) his plausive words
He scattered not in ears, but grafted them
To grow there and to bear: Let me not live.,
This his good melancholy oft began
On the Catastrophe and heel of pastime
When it was out: Let me not live. (quoth he)
After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
All but new things disdain; whose judgments are
Mere fathers of their garments: whose constancies
Expire before their fashions: this he wished.
I after him, do after him wish too:
Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,
I quickly were dissolved from my hive
To give. some Labourers room.

sp.speaker: L.2.E.
sp.l: You are loved Sir,
They that least lend it you, shall lack you first.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I fill a place I know it: how long is it Count
Since the Physician at your fathers died?
He was much famed.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Some six months since my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: If he were living, I would try him yet.
Lend me an arm: the rest have worn me out
With several applications: Nature and sickness
Debate it at their leisure. Welcome Count,
My son is no dearer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Thank your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: I will now hear, what say you of this gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Madam the care I have had to even your content,
I wish might be found in the Calendar of my past
endeavours, for then we wound our Modesty, and make
foul the clearness of our deservings, when of ourselves
we publish them.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p:
What does this knave here? Get you gone
sirrah: the complaints I have heard of you I do not all believe,
it is my slowness that I do not: For I know you
lack not folly to commit them, and have ability enough
to make such knaveries yours.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
It is not unknown to you Madam, I am a poor
fellow.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No madam,
It is not so well that I am poor, though many
of the rich are damned, but if I may have your Ladyships
good will to go to the world, Isbell the woman and we
will do as we may.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I do beg your good will in this case.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: In what case?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
In Isbels case and mine own: service is no heritage,
and I think I shall never have the blessing of God,
till I have issue of my body: for they say barnes are blessings.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
My poor body Madam requires it, I am driven
on by the flesh, and he must needs go that the devil
drives.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Is this all your worships reason?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Faith Madam I have other holy reasons, such as
they are.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: May the world know them?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I have been Madam a wicked creature, as you
and all flesh and blood are, and indeed I do marry that
I may repent.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thy marriage sooner than thy wickedness.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I am out of friends Madam, and I hope to have
friends for my wives sake.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Such friends are thine enemies knave.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
You are shallow Madam in great friends, for the
knaves come to do that for me which I am a-weary of:
he that ears my Land, spares my team, and gives me
leave to Inn the crop: if I be his cuckold he is my drudge; he that comforts my wife, is the cherisher of
my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh and
blood, loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my flesh
and blood is my friend: ergo, he that kisses my wife is my
friend: if men could be contented to be what they are,
there were no fear in marriage, for young Charbon the
Puritan, and old Poysam the Papist, howsomever their
hearts are severed in Religion, their heads are both one,
they may jowl horns together like any Dear in the Herd.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
Wilt thou ever be a foul mouthed and calumnious
knave?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
A Prophet I Madam, and I speak the truth the
next way, for I the Ballad will repeat, which men full
true shall find, your marriage comes by destiny, your
Cuckoo sings by kind.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Get you gone sir, I will talk with you more anon.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
May it please you Madam, that he bid Hellen
come to you, of her I am to speak.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sirrah tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her, Hellen I mean.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Was this fair face the cause, quoth she,
Why the Grecians sacked Troy,
Fond done, done, fond was this King Priams joy,
With that she sighed as she stood,
And gave this sentence then, among nine bad if one be
good, among nine bad if one be good, there is yet one
good in ten.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
What, one good in ten? you corrupt the song
sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
One good woman in ten Madam, which is a purifying
of the song: would God would serve the world so
all the year, we would find no fault with the tithe woman
if I were the Parson, one in ten quoth he? if we might
have a good woman born but over every blazing star,
or at an earthquake, it would mend the Lottery well, a
man may draw his heart out ere he pluck one.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
You will begone sir knave, and do as I command
you?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
That man should be at woman's command, and
yet no hurt done, though honesty be no Puritan, yet
it will do no hurt, it will wear the Surplice of humility
over the black-gown of a big heart: I am going
forsooth, the business is for Helen to come hither.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Well now.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
I know Madam you love your Gentlewoman
entirely.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
Faith I do: her Father bequeathed her to me,
and she herself without other advantage, may lawfully
make title to as much love as she finds, there is
more owing her than is paid, and more shall be paid
her then she will demand.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
Madam, I was very late more near her than
I think she wished me, alone she was, and did
communicate to herself her own words to her
own ears, she thought, I dare vow for her, they
touched not any stranger sense, her matter was, she
loved your Son; Fortune she said was no goddess,
that had put such difference betwixt their two
estates: Love no god, that would not extend his might
only, where qualities were level, Queen of Virgins,
that would suffer her poor Knight surprised
without rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward:
This she delivered in the most bitter touch of
sorrow that ere I heard Virgin exclaim in, which I held
my duty speedily to acquaint you withal, sithence in
the loss that may happen, it concerns you something
to know it.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
You have discharged this honestly, keep it
to yourself, many likelihoods informed me of this
before, which hung so; tottering in the balance, that
I could neither believe nor misdoubt: pray you
leave me, stall this in your bosom, and I thank
you for your honest care: I will speak with you further
anon.

sp.speaker: Old.Cou.
sp.p:
Even so it was with me when I was young:
If ever we are natures, these are ours, this thorne
Doth to our Rose of youth rightly belong
Our blood to us, this to our blood is born, It is the show, and seal of natures truth,
Where loves strong passion is impressed in youth,
By our remembrances of days forgone,
Such were our faults, or then we thought them none,
Her eye is sick of it, I observe her now.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p: What is your pleasure Madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.Cou.
sp.p: You know Hellen I am a mother to you.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p: Mine honourable Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ol.Cou.
sp.l: Nay a mother, why not a mother? when I said a mother
Methought you saw a serpent, what is in mother,
That you start at it? I say I am your mother,
And put you in the Catalogue of those
That were enwombed mine, it is often seen
Adoption strives with nature, and choice breeds
A native slip to us from foreign seeds:
You never oppressed me with a mothers groan,
Yet I express to you a mothers care,
(Gods mercy maiden) does it curd thy blood
To say I am thy mother? what is the matter,
That this distempered messenger of wet?
The many coloured Iris rounds thine eye?
~~ Why, that you are my daughter?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: That I am not.

sp.speaker: Old.Cou.
sp.l: I say I am your Mother.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Pardon Madam.
The Count Rosillion cannot be my brother:
I am from humble, he from honoured name:
No note upon my Parents, his all noble,
My Master, my dear Lord he is, and I
His servant live., and will his vassal die:
He must not be my brother.

sp.speaker: Ol.Cou.
sp.l: Nor I your Mother.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: You are my mother Madam, would you were
So that my Lord your son were not my brother,
Indeed my mother, or were you both our mothers,
I care no more for, than I do for heaven,
So I were not his sister, can it no other,
But I your daughter, he must be my brother

sp.speaker: Old.Cou.
sp.l: Yes Hellen, you might be my daughter-in-law,
God shield you mean it not, daughter and mother
So strive upon your pulse; what pale again?
My fear hath catched your fondness! now I see
The mystery of your loveliness, and find
Your salt tears head, now to all sense it is gross:
You love my son, invention is ashamed
Against the proclamation of thy passion
To say thou dost not: therefore tell me true,
But tell me then it is so, for look, thy cheeks
Confess it the one tooth to the other, and thine eyes
See it so grossly shown in thy behaviours,
That in their kind they speak it, only sin
And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue
That truth should be suspected, speak, is it so?
If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew:
If it be not, forswear it however I charge thee,
As heaven shall work in me for thine avail
To tell me truly.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Good Madam pardon me.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Do you love my Son?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Your pardon noble Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Love you my Son?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Do not you love him Madam?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Go not about; my love hath in it a bond
Whereof the world takes note: Come, come, disclose:
The state of your affection, for your passions
Have to the full appeached.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Then I confess
Here on my knee, before high heaven and you,
That before you, and next unto high heaven, I love your Son:
My friends were poor but honest, so is my love:
Be not offended, for it hurts not him
That he is loved of me; I follow him not
By any token of presumptuous suite,
Nor would I have him, till I do deserve him,
Yet never know how that desert should be:
I know I love in vain, strive against hope:
Yet in this captious, and untenable Sieve.
I still pour in the waters of my love
And lack not to lose still; thus Indian-like
Religious in mine error, I adore
The Sun that looks upon his worshipper,
But knows of him no more. My dearest Madam,
Let not your hate encounter with my love,
For loving where you do; but if yourself,
Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth,
Did ever, in so true a flame of liking,
Wish chastely, and love dearly, that your Dian
Was both herself and love, O then give. pity
To her whose state is such, that cannot choose
But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
That seeks not to find that, her search implies,
But riddle-like, lives sweetly where she dies.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Had you not lately an intent, speak truly,
To go to Paris?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Madam I had.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Wherefore? tell true.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I will tell truth, by grace itself I swear:
You know my Father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading
And manifest experience, had collected
For general sovereignty: and that he willed me
In heedfullest reservation to bestow them,
As notes, whose faculties inclusive were,
More than they were in note: Amongst the rest,
There is a remedy, approved, set down,
To cure the desperate languishings whereof
The King is rendered lost.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: This was your motive for Paris, was it, speak?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: My Lord, your son, made me to think of this;
Else Paris, and the medicine, and the King,
Had from the conversation of my thoughts,
Happily been absent then.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: But think you Hellen,
If you should tender your supposed aid,
He would receive it? He and his Physicians
Are of a mind, he, that they cannot help him:
They, that they cannot help, how shall they credit
A poor unlearned Virgin, when the Schools
Embowelled of their doctrine, have left off
The danger to itself.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: There is something in it
More than my Fathers skill, which was the greatest
Of his profession, that his good receipt,
Shall for my legacy be sanctified
By the luckiest stars in heaven, and would your honour
But give. me leave to try success, I would venture
The well lost life of mine, on his Graces cure,
By such a day, an hour.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Dost thou believe it?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Aye Madam knowingly.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Why Hellen thou shalt have my leave and love,
Means and attendants, and my loving greetings
To those of mine in Court, I will stay at home
And pray Gods blessing into thy attempt:
Begone tomorrow, and be sure of this,
What I can help thee to, thou shalt not miss.

div2.head: Actus Secundus.
div2.stage:
Enter the King with diuers young Lords, taking leaue for
the Florentine warre: Count, Rosse, and
Parrolles. Florish Cornets.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell young Lords, these warlike principles
Do not throw from you, and you my Lords farewell:
Share the advice betwixt you, if both gain, all
The gift doth stretch itself as it is received,
And is enough for both.

sp.speaker: Lord.G.
sp.l: It is our hope sir,
After well entered soldiers, to return And find your grace in health.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
Will not confess he owes the malady
That doth my life besiege: farewell young Lords,
Whether I live. or die, be you the sons
Of worthy French men: let higher Italy
(Those bated that inherit but the fall
Of the last Monarchy) see that you come
Not to woo honour, but to wed it, when
The bravest questant shrinks: find what you seek,
That fame may cry you loud: I say farewell.

sp.speaker: L.G.
sp.l: Health at your bidding serve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them,
They say our French, lack language to deny
If they demand: beware of being Captives
Before you serve.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Our hearts receive your warnings.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell, come hither to me.

sp.speaker: Lo. G.
sp.l: O my sweet Lord that you will stay behind us.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.l: It is not his fault the spark.

sp.speaker: 2.Lo. E.
sp.l: O it is brave wars.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.l: Most admirable, I have seen those wars.

sp.speaker: Rossill.
sp.l: I am commanded here, and kept a coil with,
Too young, and the next year, and it is too early.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.l: If thy mind stand to it boy,
Steal away bravely.

sp.speaker: Rossill.
sp.l: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,
Creaking my shoes on the plain Masonry,
Till honour be bought up, and no sword worn
But one to dance with: by heaven, I will steal away.

sp.speaker: Lo. G.
sp.l: There is honour in the theft.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.l: Commit it Count.

sp.speaker: 2.Lo. E.
sp.l: I am your accessory, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I grow to you, and our parting is a tortured body.

sp.speaker: Lo. G.
sp.l: Farewell Captain.

sp.speaker: 2.Lo. E.
sp.l: Sweet Monsieur Parolles.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.p:
Noble Heroes; my sword and yours are kin,
good sparks and lustrous, a word good metals. You
shall find in the Regiment of the Spinij, one Captain
Spurio his cicatrice, with an Emblem of war here on
his sinister cheek; it was this very sword entrenched it:
say to him I live., and observe his reports for me.

sp.speaker: Lo.G.
sp.p: We shall noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.p:
Mars dote on you for his novices, what will
ye do?

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: Stay the King.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.p:
Use a more spacious ceremony to the Noble
Lords, you have restrained yourself within the List of
too cold an adieu: be more expressive to them; for they
wear themselves in the cap of the time, there do muster
true gate; eat, speak, and move under the influence of
the most received star, and though the devil lead the
measure, such are to be followed: after them, and take a
more dilated farewell.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: And I will do so.

sp.speaker: Parr.
sp.p:
Worthy fellows, and like to prove most sinewy
sword-men.

sp.speaker: L.Laf.
sp.l: Pardon my Lord for me and for my tidings.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will see thee to stand up.

sp.speaker: L.Laf.
sp.l: Then here is a man stands that has brought his pardon,
I would you had kneeled my Lord to ask me mercy,
And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I would I had, so I had broke thy pate
And asked thee mercy for it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Good faith across, but my good Lord it is thus,
Will you be cured of your infirmity?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: O will you eat no grapes my royal fox?
Yes but you will, my noble grapes, and if
My royal fox could reach them: I have seen a medicine
That is able to breath life into a stone,
Quicken a rock, and make you dance Canari
With sprightly fire and motion, whose simple touch
Is powerful to arayse King Pippen, nay
To give. great Charlemaine a pen in his hand
And write to her a love-line.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What her is this?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Why doctor she: my Lord, there is one arrived,
If you will see her: now by my faith and honour,
If seriously I may convey my thoughts
In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
With one, that in her sex, her years, profession,
Wisdom and constancy, hath amazed me more
Than I dare blame my weakness: will you see her?
For that is her demand, and know her business?
That done, laugh well at me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now good Lafew,
Bring in the admiration, that we with thee
May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
By wondering how thou tookest it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Nay, I will fit you,
And not be all day neither.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Nay, come your ways.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This haste hath wings indeed.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Nay, come your ways,
This is his Majesty, say your mind to him,
A Traitor you do look like, but such traitors
His Majesty seldom fears, I am Cresseds Uncle,
That dare leave two together, fare you well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now fair one, does your business follow us?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord,
Gerard de Narbon was my father,
In what he did profess, well found.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I knew him.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: The rather will I spare my praises towards him,
Knowing him is enough: on his bed of death,
Many receipts he gave me, chiefly one,
Which as the dearest issue of his practice
And of his old experience, the only darling,
He bad me store up, as a triple eye,
Safer than mine own two: more dear I have so,
And hearing your high Majesty is touched
With that malignant cause, wherein the honour
Of my dear fathers gift, stands chief in power,
I come to tender it, and my appliance,
With all bound humbleness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We thank you maiden,
But may not be so credulous of cure,
When our most learned Doctors leave us, and
The congregated College have concluded,
That labouring Art can never ransom nature
From her unaidable estate: I say we must not
So stain our judgment, or corrupt our hope,
To prostitute our past-cure malady
To empirics, or to dissever so
Our great self and our credit, to esteem
A senseless help, when help past sense we deem.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: My duty then shall pay me for my pains:
I will no more enforce mine office on you,
Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts,
A modest one to bear me back again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot give. thee less to be called grateful:
Thou thoughtest to help me, and such thanks I give.,
As one near death to those that wish him live.:
But what at full I know, thou knowest no part,
I knowing all my peril, thou no Art.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: What I can do, can do no hurt to try,
Since you set up your rest against remedy:
He that of greatest works is finisher,
Oft does them by the weakest minister:
So holy Writ, in babes hath judgment shown,
When Judges have been babes; great floods have flown
From simple sources: and great Seas have dried
When Miracles have by the greatest been denied.
Oft expectation fails, and most oft there
Where most it promises: and oft it hits,
Where hope is coldest, and despair most shifts.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I must not hear thee, fare thee well kind maid,
Thy pains not used, must by thyself be paid,
Proffers not took, reap thanks for their reward.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Inspired Merit so by breath is bard,
It is not so with him that all things knows
As it is with us, that square our guess by shows:
But most it is presumption in us, when
The help of heaven we count the act of men.
Dear sir, to my endeavours give. consent,
Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an Imposture, that proclaim
Myself against the level of mine aim,
But know I think, and think I know most sure,
My Art is not past power, nor you past cure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou so confident? Within what space
Hopest thou my cure?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: The greatest grace lending grace,
Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring,
Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
Moist Hesperus hath quenched her sleepy Lamp:
Or four and twenty times the Pilots glass
Hath told the thievish minutes, how they pass:
What is infirm, from your sound parts shall fly,
Health shall live. free, and sickness freely die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Upon thy certainty and confidence,
What darest thou venture?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Tax of impudence,
A strumpets boldness, a divulged shame
Traduced by odious ballads: my maidens name
Seared otherwise, ne worse of worst extended
With vildest torture, let my life be ended.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
His powerful sound, within an organ weak:
And what impossibility would slay
In common sense, sense saves another way:
Thy life is dear, for all that life can rate
Worth name of life, in thee hath estimate:
Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all
That happiness and prime, can happy call:
Thou this to hazard, needs must intimate
Skill infinite, or monstrous desperate,
Sweet practiser, thy Physic I will try,
That ministers thine own death if I die.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If I break time, or flinch in property
Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die,
And well deserved: not helping, death is my fee,
But if I help, what do you promise me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Make thy demand.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But will you make it even?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Aye by my Sceptre, and my hopes of help.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Then shalt thou give. me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
My low and humble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy state:
But such a one thy vassal, whom I know
Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Here is my hand, the premises observed,
Thy will by my performance shall be served:
So make the choice of thy own time, for I
Thy resolved Patient, on thee still rely:
More should I question thee, and more I must,
Though more to know, could not be more to trust:
From whence thou camest, how tended on, but rest
Unquestioned welcome, and undoubted blessed.
Give me some help here ho, if thou proceed,
As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Come on sir, I shall now put you to the height
of your breeding.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
I will show myself. highly fed, and lowly
taught, I know my business is but to the Court.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
To the Court, why what place make you special,
when you put off that with such contempt, but to
the Court?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly Madam, if God have lent a man any manners,
he may easily put it off at Court: he that cannot
make a leg, put off his cap, kiss his hand, and say nothing,
has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed
such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the
Court, but for me, I have an answer will serve all men.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Marry that is a bountiful answer that fits all
questions.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
It is like a Barbers chair that fits all buttocks,
the pin buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawn buttock,
or any buttock.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an Attorney,
as your French Crown for your taffety punk, as
Tibs rush for Toms fore-finger, as a pancake for shrove tuesday,
a Morris for May-day, as the nail to his hole,
the Cuckold to his horn, as a scolding quean to a
wrangling knave, as the Nuns lip to the Friars mouth,
nay as the pudding to his skin.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for
all questions?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
From below your Duke, to beneath your Constable,
it will fit any question.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
It must be an answer of most monstrous size,
that must fit all demands.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But a trifle neither in good faith, if the learned
should speak truth of it: here it is, and all that belongs
to it. Ask me if I am a Courtier, it shall do you no
harm to learn.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
To be young again if we could: I will be a
fool in question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I pray you sir, are you a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O Lord sir there is a simple putting off: more,
more, a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord sir, thick, thick, spare not me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I think sir, you can eat none of this homely
meat.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord sir; nay put me to it, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You were lately whipped sir as I think.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord sir, spare not me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Do you cry O Lord sir at your whipping, and
spare not me? Indeed your O Lord sir, is very sequent
to your whipping: you would answer very well to a
whipping if you were but bound to it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I never had worse luck in my life in my O Lord
sir: I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I play the noble housewife with the time, to entertain
it so merrily with a fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord sir, why there it serves well again.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And end sir to your business: give Hellen this,
And urge her to a present answer back,
Commend me to my kinsmen, and my son,
This is not much.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Not much commendation to them.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Not much employment for you, you understand
me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Most fruitfully, I am there, before my legegs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Haste you again.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p:
They say miracles are past, and we have our
Philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar
things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it, that we
make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming
knowledge, when we should submit ourselves to
an unknown fear.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Why it is the rarest argument of wonder, that
hath shot out in our latter times.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And so it is.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: To be relinquished of the Artists.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: So I say both of Galen and Paracelsus.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: Of all the learned and authentic fellows.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Right so I say.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: That; gave him out incurable.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why there it is, so say I too.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: Not to be helped.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Right, as it were a man assured of a ~~

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: Uncertain life, and sure death.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Just, you say well: so would I have said.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
It is indeed if you will have it in showing, you
shall read it in what do ye call there.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly Actor.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That is it, I would have said, the very same.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p:
Why your Dolphin is not lustier: fore me
I speak in respect ~~

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Nay it is strange, it is very strange, that is the
brief and the tedious of it, and he is of a most facinerious
spirit, that will not acknowledge it to be the ~~

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: Very hand of heaven.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Aye, so I say.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: In a most weak ~~

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
And debile minister great power, great transcendence,
which should indeed give. us a further use to
be made, than alone the recovery of the king, as to be

sp.speaker: Old Laf.
sp.p: Generally thankful.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I would have said it, you say well: here comes
the King.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p:
Lusty, as the Dutchman says: I will like a
maid the Better whilst I have a tooth in my head: why
he is able to lead her a Carranto.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Mor du vinager, is not this Helen?

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p: Fore God I think so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go call before me all the Lords in Court,
Sit my preserver by thy patients side,
And with this healthful hand whose banished sense
Thou hast repealed, a second time receive
The confirmation of my promised gift,
Which but attends thy naming.
Fair Maid send forth thine eye, this youthful parcel
Of Noble Bachelors, stand at my bestowing,
Over whom both Sovereign power, and fathers voice
I have to use; thy frank election make,
Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: To each of you, one fair and virtuous Mistress;
Fall when love please, marry to each but one.

sp.speaker: Old Laf.
sp.l: I would give. bay curtal, and his furniture
My mouth no more were broken than these boys,
And writ as little beard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peruse them well:
Not one of those, but had a Noble father.

div2.stage: She addresses her to a Lord.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, heaven hath through me, restored
the king to health.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am a simple Maid, and therein wealthiest
That I protest, I simply am a Maid:
Please it your Majesty, I have done already:
The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me,
We blush that thou shouldest choose, but be refused;
Let the white death sit on thy cheek forever,
We will never come there again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Make choice and see,
Who shuns thy love, shuns all his love in me.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Now Dian from thy Altar do I fly,
And to imperial love, that God most high
Do my sighs stream: Sir, will you hear my suite?

sp.speaker: 1.Lo.
sp.l: And grant it.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Thanks sir, all the rest is mute.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.l: I had rather be in this choice, than throw
Ames-ace for my life.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: The honour sir that flames in your fair eyes,
Before I speak too threateningly replies:
Love make your fortunes twenty times above
Her that so wishes, and her humble love.

sp.speaker: 2.Lo.
sp.l: No better if you please.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My wish receive
Which great love grant, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ol.Laf.
sp.p:
Do all they deny her? If they were sons
of mine, I would have them whipped, or I would send them
to the Turk to make Eunuchs of.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Be not afraid that I your hand should take,
I will never do you wrong for your own sake:
Blessing upon your vows, and in your bed
Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed.

sp.speaker: Old Laf.
sp.p:
These boys are boys of Ice, theywill none
have here: sure they are bastards to the English, the
French never got them .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are too young, too happy, and too good
To make yourself a son out of my blood.

sp.speaker: 4.Lo.
sp.p: Fair one, I think not so.

sp.speaker: Ol.Lord
sp.p:
There is one grape yet, I am sure thy father
drunk wine. But if thou beest not an ass, I am a youth
of fourteen: I have known thee already.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I dare not say I take you, but I give.
Me and my service, ever whilst I live.
Into your guiding power: This is the man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Why then young Bertram take her she is thy
wife.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My wife my Liege? I shall beseech your highness
In such a business, give. me leave to use
The help of mine own eyes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Knowest thou not Bertram what she has
done for me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Yes my good Lord, but never hope to know
why I should marry her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Thou knowest she has raised me from my sickly
bed.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But follows it my Lord, to bring me down
Must answer for your raising? I know her well:
She had her breeding at my fathers charge:
A poor Physicians daughter my wife? Disdain
Rather corrupt me ever.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is only title thou disdainest in her, the which
I can build up: strange is it that our bloods
Of colour, weight, and heat, poured all together,
Would quite confound distinction: yet stands off
In differences so mighty. If she be
All that is virtuous (save what thou dislikest)
A poor Physicians daughter, thou dislikest
Of virtue for the name: but do not so:
From lowest place, whence virtuous things proceed,
The place is dignified by the doers deed.
Where great additions swell is, and virtue none,
It is a dropsied honour. Good alone,
Is good without a name? Vileness is so:
The property by what is is, should go,
Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair,
In these, to Nature she is immediate heir:
And these breed honour: that is honours scorn,
Which challenges itself as honours borne,
And is not like the sire: Honours thrive,
When rather from our acts we them derive
Than our foregoers: the mere words, a slave
Debauched on every tomb, on every grave:
A lying Trophy, and as oft is dumb,
Where dust, and damned oblivion is the Tomb.
Of honoured bones indeed, what should be said?
If thou canst like this creature, as a maid,
I can create the rest: Virtue, and she
Is her own dower: Honour and wealth, from me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Thou wrongest thyself, if thou shouldest strive
to choose.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That you are well restored my Lord, I am glad:
Let the rest go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Honour is at the stake, which to defeat
I must produce my power. Here, take her hand,
Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift,
That dost in vile misprision shackle up
My love, and her desert: that canst not dream,
We poising us in her defective scale,
Shall weigh thee to the beam: That wilt not know,
It is in Us to plant thine Honour, where
We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt:
Obey Our will, which travails in thy good:
Believe not thy disdain, but presently
Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
Which both thy duty owes, and Our power claims,
Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
Into the staggers, and the careless lapse
Of youth and ignorance: both my revenge and hate
Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice,
Without all terms of pity. Speak, thine answer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pardon my gracious Lord: for I submit
My fancy to your eyes, when I consider
What great creation, and what dole of honour
Flies where you bid it: I find that she which late
Was in my Nobler thoughts, most base: is now
The praised of the King, who so ennobled,
Is as it were borne so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take her by the hand,
And tell her she is thine: to whom I promise
A counterpoise: If not to thy estate,
A balance more replete.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I take her hand.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Good fortune, and the favour of the King
Smile upon this Contract: whose Ceremony
Shall seem expedient on the now borne brief,
And be performed tonight: the solemn Feast
Shall more attend upon the coming space,
Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her,
Thy love is to me Religious: else, does err.

div2.stage:
Parolles and Lafew stay behind, commenting
of this wedding.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Do you hear Monsieur? A word with you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Your Lord and Master did well to make his recantation.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Recantation? My Lord? my Master?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Aye: Is it not a Language I speak?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
A most harsh one, and not to be understood
without bloody succeeding. My Master?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Are you Companion to the Count Rosillion?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: To any Count, to all Counts: to what is man.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
To what is Counts man: Counts master is of
another style.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
You are too old sir: Let it satisfy you, you are
too old.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I must tell thee sirra, I write Man: to which
title age cannot bring thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I did think thee for two ordinaries: to be a
pretty wise fellow, thou didst make tolerable vent of
thy travel, it might pass: yet the scarves and the bannerets
about thee, did manifoldly dissuade me from believing
thee a vessel of too great a burthen. I have now
found thee, when I lose thee again, I care not: yet art
thou good for nothing but taking up, and that thou art
scarce worth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Hadst thou not the privilege of Antiquity upon
thee.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Do not plunge thyself too far. in anger, lest
thou hasten thy trial: which if, Lord have mercy on
thee for a hen, so my good window of Lettuce fare thee
well, thy casement I need not open, for I look through
thee. Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: My Lord, you give. me most egregious indignity.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Aye with all my heart, and thou art worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I have not my Lord deserved it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Yes good faith, every dram of it, and I will
not bate thee a scruple.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Well, I shall be wiser.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Even as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull
at a smack on the contrary. If ever thou beest bound
in thy scarf and beaten, thou shall find what it is to be
proud of thy bondage, I have a desire to hold my acquaintance
with thee, or rather my knowledge, that I
may say in the default, he is a man I know.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: My Lord you do me most insupportable vexation.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I would it were hell pains for thy sake, and my
poor doing eternal: for doing I am past, as I will by
thee, in what motion age will give. me leave.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace
off me; scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy Lord: Well, I must
be patient, there is no fettering of authority. I will beat
him (by my life) if I can meet him with any convenience,
if he were double and double a Lord. I will have
no more pity of his age than I would have of ~~ I will
beat him, and if I could but meet him again.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Sirrah, your Lord and master is married, there is
news for you: you have a new Mistress.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I most unfeignedly beseech your Lordship to
make some reservation of your wrongs. He is my good
Lord, whom I serve above is my master.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Who? God.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
The devil it is, that is thy master. Why dost
thou garter up thy arms of this fashion? Dost make hose
of thy sleeves? Do other servants so? Thou wert best set
thy lower part where thy nose stands. By mine Honour,
if I were but two hours younger, I would beat thee: methinkest
thou art a general offence, and every man should
beat thee: I think thou wast created for men to breath
themselves upon thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: This is hard and undeserved measure my Lord.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Go to sir, you were beaten in Italy for picking
a kernel out of a Pomegranate, you are a vagabond, and
no true traveller: you are more saucy with Lords and
honourable personages, than the Commission of your
birth and virtue gives you Heraldry. You are not worth
another word, else I would call you knave. I leave you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Good, very good, it is so then: good, very
good, let it be concealed awhile.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Undone, and forfeited to cares forever.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What is the matter sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Rossill.
sp.p:
Although before the solemn Priest I have
sworn, I will not bed her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What? what sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O my Parrolles, they have married me:
I will to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits,
The tread of a man's foot: to the wars.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
There is letters from my mother: What the import
is, I know not yet.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Aye that would be known: to the wars my boy,
to the wars:
sp.l: He wears his honour in a box unseen,
That hugs his kickie wickie here at home,
Spending his manly marrow in her arms
Which should sustain the bound and high curvet
Of Marses fiery steed: to other Regions,
France is a stable, we that dwell in it Jades,
Therefore to the war.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: It shall be so, I will send her to my house,
Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,
And wherefore I am fled: Write to the King
That which I durst not speak. His present gift
Shall furnish me to those Italian fields
Where noble fellows strike: Wars is no strife
To the dark house, and the detected wife.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Will this Caprichio hold in thee, art sure?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Go with me to my chamber, and advice me.
I will send her straight away: Tomorrow,
I will to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why these balls bound, there is noise in it. It is hard
A young man married, is a man that is marred:
Therefore away, and leave her bravely: go,
The King has done you wrong: but hush it is so.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My mother greets me kindly, is she well?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
She is not well, but yet she has her health, she is
very merry, but yet she is not well: but thanks be given
she is very well, and wants nothing in the world: but
yet she is not well.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
If she be very well, what does she ail, that she is
not very well?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Truly she is very well indeed, but for two things

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What two things?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
One, that she is not in heaven, whether God send
her quickly: the other, that she is in earth, from whence
God send her quickly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Bless you my fortunate Lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I hope sir I have your good will to have mine
own good fortune.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
You had my prayers to lead them on, and to
keep them on, have them still. O my knave, how does
my old Lady?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
So that you had her wrinkles, and I her money,
I would she did as you say.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry you are the wiser man: for many a man's
tongue shakes out his masters undoing: to say nothing,
to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing,
is to be a great part of your title, which is within a very
little of nothing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Away, thou art a knave.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
You should have said sir before a knave, thou art a
knave, that is before me thou art a knave: this had been
truth sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Go to, thou art a witty fool, I have found
thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Did you find me in yourself sir, or were you
taught to find me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The search sir was profitable, and much Fool
may you find in you, even to the worlds pleasure, and the
increase of laughter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: A good knave i'faith, and well fed.
Madam, my Lord will go away tonight,
A very serious business calls on him:
The great prerogative and rite of love,
Which as your due time claims, he does acknowledge,
But puts it off to a compelled restraint:
Whose want, and whose delay, is strewed with sweets
Which they distill now in the curbed time,
To make the coming hour overflow with joy,
And pleasure drown the brim.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What is his will else?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That you will take your instant leave of the king,
And make this haste as your own good proceeding,
Strengthened with what Apology you think
May make it probable need.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What more commands he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That having this obtained, you presently
Attend his further pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: In everything I wait upon his will.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I shall report it so.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I pray you come sirra.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
But I hope your Lordship thinks not him a
soldier.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes my Lord and of very valiant approof.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: You have it from his own deliverance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And by other warranted testimony.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Then my Dial goes not true, I took this Lark
for a bunting.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I do assure you my Lord he is very great in knowledge,
and accordingly valiant.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I have then sinned against his experience, and
transgressed against his valour, and my state that way is
dangerous, since I cannot yet find in my heart to repent:
Here he comes, I pray you make us friends, I will pursue
the amity.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: These things shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Pray you sir who is his Tailor?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
O I know him well, Aye sir, he sir is a good workman,
a very good Tailor.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Is she gone to the king?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Will she away tonight?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As you will have her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I have writ my letters, casketted my treasure,
Given order for our horses, and tonight,
When I should take possession of the Bride,
And ere I do begin.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
A good Travailer is something at the latter end
of a dinner, but one that lies three thirds, and uses a
known truth to pass a thousand nothings with, should
be once hard, and thrice beaten. God save you Captain.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Is there any unkindness between my Lord and
you Monsieur?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I know not how I have deserved to run into my
Lords displeasure.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
You have made shift to run into it, boots and
spurs and all: like him that leapt into the Custard, and
out of it you will run again, rather than suffer question
for your residence.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It may be you have mistaken him my Lord.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
And shall do so ever, though I took him at his
prayers. Fare you well my Lord, and believe this of
me, there can be no kernel in this light Nut: the soul
of this man is his clothes: Trust him not in matter of
heavy consequence: I have kept of them tame, and know
their natures. Farewell Monsieur, I have spoken better
of you, than you have or will to deserve at my hand, but
we must do good against evil.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: An idle Lord, I swear.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I think so;.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why do you not know him?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, I do know him well, and common speech
Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I have sir as I was commanded from you
Spoke with the King, and have procured his leave
For present parting, only he desires
Some private speech with you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I shall obey his will.
You must not marvel Helen at my course,
Which holds not colour with the time, nor does
The ministration, and required office
On my particular. Prepared I was not
For such a business, therefore am I found
So much unsettled: This drives me to entreat you,
That presently you take your way for home,
And rather muse than ask why I entreat you,
For my respects are better than they seem,
And my appointments have in them a need
Greater than shows itself at the first view,
To you that know them not. This to my mother,
It will be two days ere I shall see you, so
I leave you to your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Sir, I can nothing say,
But that I am your most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of that.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And ever shall
With true observance seek to eke out that
Wherein toward me my homely stars have failed
To equal my great fortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Let that go: my haste is very great. Farewell:
Hie home.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Pray sir your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, what would you say?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe,
Nor dare I say it is mine: and yet it is,
But like a timorous thief, most fain would steal
What law does vouch mine own.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Something, and scarce so much: nothing indeed,
I would not tell you what I would my Lord: Faith yes,
Strangers and foes do sunder, and not kiss.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I pray you stay not, but in haste to horse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I shall not break your bidding, good my Lord:
Where are my other men? Monsieur, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Go thou toward home, where I will never come,
Whilst I can shake my sword, or hear the drum:
Away, and for our flight.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Bravely, Coragio.

div2.head: Actus Tertius.
div2.stage:
Flourish. Enter the Duke of Florence, the two Frenchmen,
with a troop of Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: So that from point to point, now have you heard
The fundamental reasons of this war,
Whose great decision hath much blood let forth
And more thirsts after.

sp.speaker: 1.Lord
sp.l: Holy seems the quarrel
Upon your Graces part: black and fearful
On the opposer.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Therefore we marvel much our Cousin France
Would in so just a business, shut his bosom
Against our borrowing prayers.

sp.speaker: 1.Lord
sp.l: Good my Lord,
The reasons of our state I cannot yield,
But like a common and an outward man,
That the great figure of a Counsel frames,
By self-unable motion, therefore dare not
Say what I think of it, since I have found
Myself in my uncertain grounds to fail
As often as I guest.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be it his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fren.G.
sp.l: But I am sure the younger of our nature,
That surfeit on their ease, will day by day
Come here for Physic.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome shall they be:
And all the honours that can fly from us,
Shall on them settle: you know your places well,
When better fall, for your avails they fell,
Tomorrow to the the field.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
It hath happened all, as I would have had it, save
that he comes not along with her.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth I take my young Lord to be a very
melancholy man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: By what observance I pray you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why he will look upon his boot, and sing:
mend the Ruff and sing, ask questions and sing, pick
his teeth, and sing: I know a man that had this trick of
melancholy hold a goodly Manor for a song.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p:
Let me see what he writes, and when he means
to come.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I have no mind to Isbell since I was at Court.
Our old Lings, and our Isbels of the Country, are nothing
like your old Ling and your Isbels of the Court: the brains
of my Cupid is knocked out, and I begin to love, as an
old man loves money, with no stomach.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: In that you have there.

I have sent you a daughter-in-Law, she hath recovered the
King, and undone me: I have wedded her, not bedded her,
and sworn to make the not eternal. You shall hear I am
run away, know it before the report come. If there be breadth enough in the world, I will hold a long distance. My
duty to you. Your unfortunate son,
Bertram.

sp.l: This is not well rash and unbridled boy,
To fly the favours of so good a King,
To pluck his indignation on thy head,
By the misprising of a Maid too virtuous
For the contempt of Empire.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
O Madam, yonder is heavy news within between
two soldiers, and my young Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What is the matter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay there is some comfort in the news, some
comfort, your son will not be killed so soon as I thought
he would.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why should he be killed?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
So say I Madam, if he run away, as I hear he
does, the danger is in standing to it, that is the loss of
men, though it be the getting of children. Here they
come will tell you more. For my part I only hear your
son was run away.

sp.speaker: French E.
sp.l: Save you good Madam.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord is gone, forever gone.

sp.speaker: French G.
sp.l: Do not say so.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Think upon patience, pray you Gentlemen,
I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief,
That the first face of neither on the start
Can woman me unto it. Where is my son I pray you?

sp.speaker: Fren.G.
sp.l: Madam he is gone to serve the Duke of Florence,
We met him thitherward, for thence we came:
And after some dispatch in hand at Court,
Thither we bend again.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Look on his Letter Madam, here is my Passport.

sp.p:
When thou canst get the Ring upon my finger, which never
shall come off, and show me a child begotten of thy body,
that I am father to, then call me husband: but in such a (then)
I write a Never.
This is a dreadful sentence.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Brought you this Letter Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1.G.
sp.p: Aye Madam, and for the Contents sake are sorry for our pains.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: I prithee Lady have a better cheer,
If thou engrossest, all the griefs are thine,
Thou robbest me of a moiety: He was my son,
But I do wash his name out of my blood,
And thou art all my child. Towards Florence is he?

sp.speaker: Fren.G.
sp.l: Aye Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And to be a soldier.

sp.speaker: Fren.G.
sp.l: Such is his noble purpose, and believe it
The Duke will lay upon him all the honour
That good convenience claims.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Return you thither.

sp.speaker: Fren.E.
sp.l: Aye Madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

sp.p: Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France,
It is bitter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Find you that there?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Aye Madam.

sp.speaker: Fren.E.
sp.p:
It is but the boldness of his hand happily, which
his heart was not consenting to.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Nothing in France, until he have no wife:
There is nothing here that is too good for him
But only she, and she deserves a Lord
That twenty such rude boys might tend upon,
And call her hourly Mistress. Who was with him?

sp.speaker: Fren.E.
sp.p:
A servant only, and a Gentleman: which I
have sometime known.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Parolles was it not?

sp.speaker: Fren.E.
sp.p: Aye my good Lady, he.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness,
My son corrupts a well derived nature
With his inducement.

sp.speaker: Fren.E.
sp.p:
Indeed good Lady the fellow has a deal of
that, too much, which holds him much to have.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
You are welcome Gentlemen, I will entreat you
when you see my son, to tell him that his sword can
never win the honour that he looses: more I will entreat
you written to bear along.

sp.speaker: Fren.G.
sp.p:
We serve you Madam in that and all your
worthiest affairs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not so, but as we change our courtesies,
Will you draw near?

sp.p: Till I have no wife I have nothing in France.

sp.l: Nothing in France until he has no wife:
Thou shalt have none Rossillion, none in France,
Then hast thou all again: poor Lord, is it I
That chase thee from thy Country, and expose
Those tender limbs of thine, to the event
Of the none-sparing war? And is it I,
That drive thee from the sportive Court, where thou
Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark
Of smokey Muskets? O you leaden messengers,
That ride upon the violent speed of fire,
Fly with false aim, move the still-peering air
That sings with piercing, do not touch my Lord:
Whoever shoots at him, I set him there.
Whoever charges on his forward breast
I am the Caitiff that do hold him to it,
And though I kill him not, I am the cause
His death was so effected: Better it were
I met the ravine Lion when he roared
With sharpe constraint of hunger: better it were,
That all the miseries which nature owes
Were mine at once. No come thou home Rossillion,
Whence honour but of danger wins a scar,
As oft it looses all. I will be gone:
My being here it is, that holds thee hence,
Shall I stay here to do it? No, no, although
The air of Paradise did fan the house,
And Angels officed all: I will be gone,
That pitiful rumour may report my flight
To console thine ear. Come night, end day,
For with the dark (poor thief) I will steal away.

div2.stage: Flourish. Enter the Duke of Florence, Rossillion, drum and trumpets, soldiers, Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The General of our horse thou art, and we
Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence
Upon thy promising fortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sir it is
A charge too heavy for my strength, but yet
We will strive to bear it for your worthy sake,
To the extreme edge of hazard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then go thou forth,
And fortune play upon thy prosperous helm
As thy auspicious mistress.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This very day
Great Mars I put myself. into thy file,
Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove
A lover of thy drum, hater of love.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas! and would you take the letter of her:
Might you not know she would do, as she has done,
By sending me a Letter. Read it again.
I am Saint Iaques Pilgrim, thither gone:
Ambitious love hath so in me offended,
That bare-foot plod I the cold ground upon
With sanded vow my faults to have amended
Write, write, that from the bloody course of war,
My dearest Master your dear son, may hie,
Bless him at home in peace. Whilst I from far.,
His name with zealous fervor sanctify:
His taken labours bid him me forgive:
I his despiteful Iuno sent him forth,
From Courtly friends, with Camping foes to live,
Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth.
He is too good and fair for death, and me,
Whom I myself. embrace, to set him free.
Ah what sharpe stings are in her mildest words?
Rynaldo, you did never lack advice so much,
As letting her pass so: had I spoke with her,
I could have well diverted her intents,
Which thus she hath prevented.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Pardon me Madam,
If I had given you this at overnight,
She might have been overtaken: and yet she writes
Pursuit would be but vain.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What Angel shall
Bless this unworthy husband, he cannot thrive,
Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear
And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath
Of greatest Justice. Write, write Rynaldo,
To this unworthy husband of his wife,
Let every word weigh heavy of her worth,
That he does weigh too light: my greatest grief,
Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
Dispatch the most convenient messenger,
When happily he shall hear that she is gone,
He will return, and hope I may that she
Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,
Led hither by pure love: which of them both
Is dearest to me, I have no skill in sense
To make distinction: provide this Messenger:
My heart is heavy, and mine age is weak,
Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.

div2.stage:
Enter old Widdow of Florence, her daughter Violenta
and Mariana, with other
Citizens.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.l: Nay come,
For if they do approach the City,
We shall lose all the sight.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: They say, the French Count has done
Most honourable service.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It is reported,
That he has taken their greatest Commander,
And that with his own hand he slew
The Dukes brother: we have lost our labour,
They are gone a contrary way: hark,
you may know by their Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Come let us return again,
And suffice ourselves with the report of it.
Well Diana, take heed of this French Earl,
The honour of a Maid is her name,
And no Legacy is so rich
As honesty.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.l: I have told my neighbour
How you have been solicited by a Gentleman
His Companion.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p:
I know that knave, hang him, one Parolles,
a filthy Officer he is in those suggestions for the young
Earl, beware of them Diana; their promises, enticements,
oaths, tokens, and all these engines of lust, are
not the things they go under: many a maid hath been
seduced by them, and the misery is example, that so
terrible shows in the wrack of maiden-hood, cannot
for all that dissuade succession, but that they are limed
with the twigs that threatens them. I hope I need
not to advise you further, but I hope your own grace
will keep you where you are, though there were no
further danger known, but the modesty which is so
lost.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: You shall not need to fear me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I hope so: look here comes a pilgrim, I know
she will lie at my house, thither they send one another,
I will question her. God save you pilgrim, whether are
bound?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: To Saint Iaques la grand.
Where do the Palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: At the Saint Francis here beside the Port.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Is this the way?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Aye marry is it. Hark you, they come this way:
If you will tarry holy Pilgrim
But till the troops come by,
I will conduct you where you shall be lodged,
The rather for I think I know your hostess
As ample as myself..

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Is it yourself?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: If you shall please so Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: you came I think from France?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I did so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Here you shall see a Countryman of yours
That has done worthy service.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: His name I pray you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The Count Rossillion: know you such a one?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But by the ear that hears most nobly of him:
His face I know not.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Whatsoever he is
he is bravely taken here. He stole from France
As it is reported: for the King had married him
Against his liking. Think you it is so?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Aye surely mere the truth, I know his Lady.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: There is a Gentleman that serves the Count,
Reports but coarsely of her.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Monsieur Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O I believe with him,
In argument of praise, or to the worth
Of the great Count himself, she is too mean
To have her name repeated, all her deserving
Is a reserved honesty, and that
I have not heard examined.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Alas poor Lady,
It is a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a detesting Lord.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I write good creature, wheresoever she is,
Her heart weighs sadly: this young maid might do her
A shrewd turn if she pleased.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: How do you mean?
Maybe the amorous Count solicits her
In the unlawful purpose.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He does indeed,
And brokes with all that can in such a suite
Corrupt the tender honour of a Maid:
But she is armed for him, and keeps her guard
In honestest defence.

div2.stage:
Drumme and Colours.
Enter Count Rossillion, Parrolles, and the whole Armie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The goddess forbid else.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: So, now they come:
That is Anthonio the Dukes eldest son,
That Escalus.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Which is the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He,
That with the plume, it is a most gallant fellow,
I would he loved his wife: if he were honester
He were much goodlier. Is it not a handsome Gentleman

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I like him well.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: It is pity he is not honest: yond is that same knave
That leads him to these places: were I his Lady,
I would poison that vile Rascal.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Which is he?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
That Jackanapes with scarfs. Why is he
melancholy?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Perchance he is hurt in the battle.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Lose our drum? Well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He is shrewdly vexed at something. Look he
has spied us.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry hang you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
The troop is past: Come pilgrim, I will bring
you, Where you shall host: Of enjoined penitents
sp.l: There is four or five, to great Saint Iaques bound,
Already at my house.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I humbly thank you:
Please it this Matron, and this gentle Maid
To eat with us tonight, the charge and thanking
Shall be for me, and to requite you further,
I will bestow some precepts of this Virgin,
Worthy the note.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We will take your offer kindly.

div2.stage:
Enter Count Rossillion and the Frenchmen,
as at first.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord put him to it: let him
have his way.
