sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
If your Lordship find him not a-hiding,
hold me no more in your respect.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p: On my life my Lord, a bubble.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you think I am so far.
Deceived in him.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Believe it my Lord, in mine own direct
knowledge, without any malice, but to speak of him
as my kinsman, he is a most notable Coward, an infinite
and endless Liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the
owner of no one good quality, worthy your Lordships
entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
It were fit you knew him, least reposing too
far. in his virtue which he hath not, he might at some
great and trusty business, in a main danger, fail
you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I would I knew in what particular action to try
him.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
None better than to let him fetch off his
drum, which you hear him so confidently undertake
to do.

sp.speaker: C.E.
sp.p:
I with a troop of Florentines will suddenly surprise
him; such I will have whom I am sure he knows
not from the enemy: we will bind and hoodwink
him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he is carried
into the Leaguer of the adversaries, when we bring
him to our own tents: be but your Lordship present
at his examination, if he do not for the promise of his
life, and in the highest compulsion of base fear, offer to
betray you, and deliver all the intelligence in his power
against you, and that with the divine forfeit of his
soul upon oath, never trust my judgment in anything.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
O for the love of laughter, let him fetch his
drum, he says he has a stratagem for it: when your
Lordship sees the bottom of this success in it, and to
what mettle this counterfeit lump of ours will be melted
if you give. him not Iohn drums entertainment,
your inclining cannot be removed. Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
O for the love of laughter hinder not the honour
of his design, let him fetch off his drum in any
hand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
How now Monsieur? This drum sticks sorely
in your disposition.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: A pox on it, let it go, it is but a drum.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
But a drum: Is it but a drum? A drum so
lost. There was excellent command, to charge in with
our horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own
soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
That was not to be blamed in the command
of the service: it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself
could not have prevented, if he had been there to
command.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success:
some dishonour we had in the loss of that drum,
but it is not to be recovered.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: It might have been recovered.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It might, but it is not now.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
It is to be recovered, but that the merit of service
is seldom attributed to the true and exact performer,
I would have that drum or another, or hic iacet.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Why if you have a stomach, to it Monsieur: if
you think your mystery in stratagem, can bring this
instrument of honour again into his native quarter, be
magnanimous in the enterprise and go on, I will grace
the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you speed well in
it, the Duke shall both speak of it, and extend to you
what further becomes his greatness, even to the utmost
syllable of your worthiness.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: By the hand of a soldier I will undertake it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But you must not now slumber in it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I will about it this evening, and I will presently
pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my
certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation:
and by midnight look to hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are
gone about it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I know not what the success will be my Lord,
but the attempt I vow.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I know thou art valiant,
And to the possibility of thy soldiership,
Will subscribe for thee: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I love not many words.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
No more than a fish loves water. Is not this
a strange fellow my Lord, that so confidently seems to
undertake this business, which he knows is not to be
done, damns himself to do, and dares better be damned
than to do it.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
You do not know him my Lord as we do,
certain it is that he will steal himself into a man's favour,
and for a week escape a great deal of discoveries,
but when you find him out, you have him ever after.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Why do you think he will make no deed at
all of this that so seriously he does address himself
unto?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
None in the world, but return with an invention,
and clap upon you two or three probable lies:
but we have almost embossed him, you shall see his fall tonight;
for indeed he is not for your Lordships respect.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
We will make you some sport with the Fox
ere we case him. He was first smoked by the old Lord
Lafew, when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what
a sprat you shall find him, which you shall see this very
night.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.l: I must go look my twigs,
He shall be caught.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Your brother he shall go along with me.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.l: As it please your Lordship, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you
The Lass I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.l: But you say she is honest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: That is all the fault: I spoke with her but once,
And found her wondrous cold, but I sent to her
By this same Coxcomb that we have in the wind
Tokens and Letters, which she did resend,
And this is all I have done: She is a fair creature,
Will you go see her?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p: With all my heart my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If you misdoubt me that I am not she,
I know not how I shall assure you further,
But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Though my estate be fallen, I was well borne,
Nothing acquainted with these businesses,
And would not put my reputation now
In any staining act.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Nor would I wish you.
First give. me trust, the Count he is my husband,
And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken,
Is so from word to word: and then you cannot
By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,
Err in bestowing it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I should believe you,
For you have showed me that which well approves
You are great in fortune.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Take this purse of Gold,
And let me buy your friendly help thus far.,
Which I will over-pay, and pay again
When I have found it. The Count he woes your daughter,
Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
Resolve to carry her: let her in fine consent
As we will direct her how it is best to bear it:
Now his important blood will naught deny,
That she will demand: a ring the County wears,
That downward hath succeeded in his house
From son to son, some four or five descents,
Since the first father wore it. This Ring he holds
In most rich choice: yet in his idle fire,
To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,
However repented after.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Now I see the bottom of your purpose.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: You see it lawful then, it is no more,
But that your daughter ere she seems as won,
Desires this Ring; appoints him an encounter;
In fine, delivers me to fill the time,
Herself most chastely absent: after
To marry her, I will add three thousand Crowns
To what is past already.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I have yielded:
Instruct my daughter how she shall persevere,
That time and place with this deceit so lawful
May prove coherent. Every night he comes
With Musics of all sorts, and songs composed
To her unworthiness: It nothing steeds us
To chide him from our eaves, for he persists
As if his life lay on it.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Why then tonight
Let us assay our plot, which if it speed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed;
And lawful meaning in a lawful act,
Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact.
But let us about it.

div2.head: Actus Quartus.
div2.stage:
Enter one of the Frenchmen, with fiue or sixe other
soldiers in ambush.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord E.
sp.p:
He can come no other way but by this hedge
corner: when you sally upon him, speak what terrible
Language you will: though you understand it not yourselves,
no matter: for we must not seem to understand
him, unless someone among us, whom we must produce
for an Interpreter.

sp.speaker: 1.Sol.
sp.p: Good Captain, let me be the Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Lor.E.
sp.p:
Art not acquainted with him? knows he not
thy voice?

sp.speaker: 1.Sol.
sp.p: No sir I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p:
But what linsie wolsy hast thou to speak to us
again.
Even such as you speak to me.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p:
He must think us some band of strangers, in the
adversaries entertainment. Now he hath a smack of all
neighbouring Languages: therefore we must everyone
be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we speak
one to another: so we seem to know, is to know straight
our purpose: Chuff's language, gabble enough, and
good enough. As for you interpreter, you must seem
very politic. But couch ho, here he comes, to beguile
two hours in a sleep, and then to return and swear
the lies he forges.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Ten o'clock: Within these three hours it will
be time enough to go home. What shall I say I have
done? It must be a very plausive invention that carries
it. They begin to smoke me, and disgraces have of
late, knocked too often at my door: I find my tongue
is too foolhardy, but my heart hath the fear of Mars
before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of
my tongue.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p:
This is the first truth that ere thine own tongue
was guilty of.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
What the devil should move me to undertake
the recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the
impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I
must give. myself. some hurts, and say I got them in exploit:
yet slight ones will not carry it. They will say,
came you off with so little? And great ones I dare not
give., wherefore what is the instance. Tongue, I must put
you into a Butter-womans mouth, and buy myself another
of Baiazeths Mule, if you prattle me into these
perils.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p:
Is it possible he should know what he is, and
be that he is.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I would the cutting of my garments would serve
the turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: We cannot afford you so.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Or the baring of my beard, and to say it was in
stratagem.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: It would not do.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: Hardly serve.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Though I swore I leapt from the window of the
Citadel.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: How deep?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Thirty fathom.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p:
Three great oaths would scarce make that be
believed.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I would I had any drum of the enemies, I
would swear I recovered it.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: You shall hear one anon.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: A drum now of the enemies.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O ransom, ransom,
Do not hide mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I know you are the Muskos Regiment,
And I shall lose my life for want of language.
If there be here German or Dane, Low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him speak to me,
I will discover that, which shall undo the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Boskos vauvado, I understand thee, and can speak
thy tongue: Kerelybonto sir, betake thee to thy faith, for
seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: O pray, pray, pray,
Manka reuania dulche.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: Oscorbidulchos voliuorco.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: The General is content to spare thee yet,
And hoodwinked as thou art, will lead thee on
To gather from thee. Happily thou mayst inform
Something to save thy life.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O let me live.
And all the secrets of our camp I will show,
Their force, their purposes: Nay, I will speak that,
Which you will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: But wilt thou faithfully?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: If I do not, damn me.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: Acordo linta.
Come on, thou are granted space.

sp.speaker: L.E.
sp.l: Go tell the Count Rossillion and my brother,
We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled
Till we do hear from them.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Captain I will.

sp.speaker: L.E.
sp.l: He will betray us all unto ourselves,
Inform on that.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: So I will sir.

sp.speaker: L.E.
sp.l: Till then I will keep him dark and safely locked.

div2.stage:
Enter Bertram, and the Maide called
Diana.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: They told me that your name was Fontybell.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No my good Lord, Diana.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Titled Goddess,
And worth it with addition: but fair soul,
In your fine frame hath love no quality?
If the quick fire of youth light not your mind,
You are no Maiden but a monument
When you are dead you should be such a one
As you are now: for you are cold and stern,
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet self was got.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: She then was honest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So should you be.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No:
My mother did but duty, such (my Lord)
As you owe to your wife.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No more of that:
I prithee do not strive against my vows:
I was compelled to her, but I love thee
By loves own sweet constraint, and will forever
Do thee all rights of service.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Aye so you serve us
Till we serve you: But when you have our Roses,
You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves,
And mock us with our bareness.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How have I sworn.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: It is not the many oaths that makes the truth,
But the plain single vow, that is vowed true:
What is not holy, that we swear not by,
But take the highest to witness: then pray you tell me,
If I should swear by Ioues great attributes,
I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,
When I did love you ill? This has no holding
To swear by him whom I protest to love
That I will work against him. Therefore your oaths
Are words and poor conditions, but unsealed
At least in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Change it, change it:
Be not so holy cruel: Love is holy,
And my integrity never knew the crafts
That you do charge men with: Stand no more off,
But give. thyself unto my sick desires,
Who then recovers. Say thou art mine, and ever
My love as it begins, shall so persevere.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I see that men make ropes in such a scar,
That we will forsake ourselves. Give me that Ring.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I will lend it thee my dear; but have no power
To give. it from me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Will you not my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is an honour longing to our house,
Bequeathed down from many Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquy in the world,
In me to lose.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Mine Honor is such a Ring,
My chastity is the Jewel of our house,
Bequeathed down from many Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquy in the world,
In me to lose. Thus your own proper wisdom
Brings in the Champion honour on my part,
Against your vain assault.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here, take my Ring,
My house, mine honour, yea my life be thine,
And I will be bid by thee.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber window:
I will order take, my mother shall not hear.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you have conquered my yet maiden-bed,
Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:
My reasons are most strong, and you shall know them,
When back again this Ring shall be delivered:
And on your finger in the night, I will put
Another Ring, that what in time proceeds,
May token to the future, our past deeds.
Adieu till then, then fail not: you have won
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: For which, live. long to thank both heaven and me,
You may so in the end.
My mother told me just how he would woo,
As if she sate in his heart. She says, all men
Have the like oaths: He had sworn to marry me
When his wife is dead: therefore I will lie with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,
Marry that will, I live. and die a Maid:
Only in this disguise, I think it no sin,
To cozen him that would unjustly win.

div2.stage:
Enter the two French Captaines, and some two or three
Souldiours.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: You have not given him his mothers letter.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
I have delivered it an hour since, there is something
in it that stings his nature: for on the reading it,
he changed almost into another man.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
He has much worthy blame laid upon him,
for shaking off so good a wife, and so sweet a Lady.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Especially, he hath incurred the everlasting
displeasure of the King, who had even tuned his bounty
to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a thing, but
you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
When you have spoken it it is dead, and I am
the grave of it.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
He hath perverted a young Gentlewoman
here in Florence, of a most chaste renown, and this night
he fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour: he hath
given her his monumental Ring, and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Now God delay our rebellion as we are ourselves,
what things are we.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Merely our own traitors. And as in the
common course of all treasons, we still see them reveal
themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends: so
he that in this action contrives against his own Nobility
in his proper stream, overflows himself.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Is it not meant damnable in us, to be Trumpeters
of our unlawful intents? We shall not then have
his company tonight?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Not till after midnight: for he is dieted to
his hour.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
That approaches apace: I would gladly have
him see his company anathematized, that he might take
a measure of his own judgments, wherein so curiously
he had set this counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
We will not meddle with him till he come;
for his presence must be the whip of the other.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
In the mean time, what hear you of these
Wars?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p: I hear there is an overture of peace.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: Nay, I assure you a peace concluded.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
What will Count Rossillion do then? Will he
travail higher, or return again into France?

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
I perceive by this demand, you are not altogether
of his council.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Let it be forbid sir, so should I be a great
deal of his act.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Sir, his wife some two months since fled
from his house, her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Iaques
le grand; which holy undertaking, with most austere
sanctimony she accomplished: and there residing,
the tenderness of her Nature, became as a prey to her
grief: in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and now
she sings in heaven.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p: How is this justified?

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
The stronger part of it by her own Letters,
which makes her story true, even to the point of her
death: her death itself, which could not be her office
to say, is come: was faithfully confirmed by the Rector
of the place.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p: Hath the Count all this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Aye, and the particular confirmations, point
from point, to the full arming of the verity.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
I am heartily sorry that he will be glad of
this.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
How mightily sometimes, we make us comforts
of our losses.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
And how mightily some other times, we
drown our gain in tears, the great dignity that his
valour hath here acquired for him, shall at home be encountered
with a shame as ample.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
The web of our life, is of a mingled yarn,
good and ill together: our virtues would be proud, if
our faults whipped them not, and our crimes would despair
if they were not cherished by our virtues.
How now? Where is your master?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
He met the Duke in the street sir, of whom he
hath taken a solemn leave: his Lordship will next
morning for France. The Duke hath offered him Letters
of commendations to the King.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
They shall be no more than needful there,
if they were more than they can commend.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
They cannot be too sweet for the Kings tartness,
here is his Lordship now. How now my Lord,
is it not after midnight?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I have tonight despatched sixteen businesses, a
months length apiece, by an abstract of success: I
have congied with the Duke, done my adieu with his
nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her, writ to my Lady
mother, I am returning, entertained my Convoy, and
between these main parcels of dispatch, affected many
nicer needs: the last was the greatest, but that I have
not ended yet.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
If the business be of any difficulty, and this
morning your departure hence, it requires haste of your
Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I mean the business is not ended, as fearing
to hear of it hereafter: but shall we have this dialogue
between the Fool and the Soldier. Come, bring
forth this counterfeit module, has deceived me, like a
double-meaning Prophesier.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
Bring him forth, has sat in the stocks all night
poor gallant knave.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
No matter, his heels have deserved it, in usurping
his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
I have told your Lordship already: The
stocks carry him. But to answer you as you would be
understood, he weeps like a wench that had shed her
milk, he hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he
supposes to be a Friar, from the time of his remembrance
to this very instant disaster of his setting in the stocks:
and what think you he hath confessed?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nothing of me, has he?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
His confession is taken, and it shall be read
to his face, if your Lordship be in it, as I believe you
are, you must have the patience to hear it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
A plague upon him, muffled; he can say nothing
of me: hush, hush.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: Hoodman comes: Portotartarossa.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
He calls for the tortures, what will you say
without them .

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I will confess what I know without constraint,
If ye pinch me like a Pasty, I can say no more.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Bosko Chimurcho.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
You are a merciful General: Our General
bids you answer to what I shall ask you out of a Note.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And truly, as I hope to live..

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
First demand of him, how many horse the Duke
is strong. What say you to that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Five or six thousand, but very weak and unserviceable:
the troops are all scattered, and the Commanders
very poor rogues, upon my reputation and
credit, and as I hope to live..

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Shall I set down your answer so?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Do, I will take the Sacrament on it, how and which
way you will: all is one to him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What a past-saving slave is this?

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
You are deceived my Lord, this is Monsieur
Parrolles the gallant militarist, that was his own phrase
that had the whole theoric of war in the knot of his
scarf, and the practise in the chape of his dagger.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
I will never trust a man again, for keeping
his sword clean, nor believe he can have every thing
in him, by wearing his apparel neatly.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Well, that is set down.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Five or six thousand horse I said, I will say true,
or thereabouts set down, for I will speak truth.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: He is very near the truth in this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But I con him no thanks for it in the nature he delivers it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Poor rogues, I pray you say.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Well, that is set down.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I humbly thank you sir, a truth is a truth, the
Rogues are marvelous poor.

sp.speaker: Interp.
sp.p:
Demand of him of what strength they are afoot.
What say you to that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
By my troth sir, if I were to live. this present
hour, I will tell true. Let me see, Spurio a hundred and
fifty, Sebastian so many, Corambus so many, Iaques so
many: Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowicke, and Gratij, two hundred
fifty each: Mine own Company, Chitopher, Vaumond,
Bentij, two hundred fifty each: so that the muster file, rotten and sound, upon my life amounts not to fifteen
thousand pole, half of the which, dare not shake
the snow from off their Cassocks, lest they shake themselves
to pieces.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What shall be done to him?

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand
of him my condition: and what credit I have with the
Duke.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Well that is set down: you shall demand of
him, whether one Captain Dumaine be in the Camp, a
Frenchman: what his reputation is with the Duke, what
his valour, honesty, and expertness in wars: or whether
he thinks it were not possible with well-weighing
sums of gold to corrupt him to a revolt. What say you
to this? What do you know of it?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I beseech you let me answer to the particular of
the interrogatories. Demand them singly.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Do you know this Captain Dumaine?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I know him, he was a Botchers Prentice in Paris,
from whence he was whipped for getting the Shrives fool
with child, a dumb innocent that could not say him
nay.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Nay, by your leave hold your hands, though I
know his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Well, is this Captain in the Duke of Florences
camp?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Upon my knowledge he is, and lousy.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Nay look not so upon me: we shall hear of
your Lord anon.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What is his reputation with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
The Duke knows him for no other, but a poor
Officer of mine, and writ to me this other day, to turn
him out of the band. I think I have his Letter in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Marry we will search.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
In good sadness I do not know, either it is there,
or it is upon a file with the Dukes other Letters, in my
Tent.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Here it is, here is a paper, shall I read it to you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I do not know if it be it or no.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Our Interpreter does it well.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: Excellently.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Dian, the Count is a fool, and full of gold.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
That is not the Dukes letter sir: that is an advertisement
to a proper maid in Florence, one Diana, to
take heed of the allurement of one Count Rossillion, a
foolish idle boy: but for all that very ruttish. I pray you
sir put it up again.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Nay, I will read it first by your favour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My meaning in it I protest was very honest in the
behalf of the maid: for I knew the young Count to be a
dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to Virginity,
and devours up all the fry it finds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Damnable both-sides rogue.

sp.l: When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it:
After he scores, he never pays the score:
Half won is match well made, match and well make it,
He never pays after-debts, take it before,
And say a soldier (Dian) told thee this:
Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss.
For count of this, the Count is a Fool I know it,
Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.
Thine as he vowed to thee in thine ear,
Parolles.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
He shall be whipped through the Army with this
rime in his forehead.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
This is your devoted friend sir, the manifold
Linguist, and the army-potent soldier.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I could endure anything before but a Cat, and
now he is a Cat to me.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
I perceive sir by your Generals looks, we shall
be fain to hang you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My life sir in any case: Not that I am afraid to
die, but that my offences being many, I would repent
out the remainder of Nature. Let me live. sir in a dungeon,
in the stocks, or anywhere, so I may live.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
We will see what may be done, so you confess
freely: therefore once more to this Captain Dumaine:
you have answered to his reputation with the Duke, and
to his valour. What is his honesty?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
He will steal sir an Egg out of a Cloister: for
rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus. He professes
not keeping of oaths, in breaking them he is stronger than
Hercules. He will lie sir, with such volubility, that you
would think truth were a fool: drunkenness is his best
virtue, for he will be swine-drunk, and in his sleep he
does little harm, save to his bedclothes about him:
but they know his conditions, and lay him in straw. I
have but little more to say sir of his honesty, he has every
thing that an honest man should not have; what an
honest man should have, he has nothing.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: I begin to love him for this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
For this description of thine honesty? A pox
upon him for me, he is more and more a Cat.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What say you to his expertness in war?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Faith sir, has led the drum before the English
Tragedians: to belie him I will not, and more of his
soldiership I know not, except in that Country, he had
the honour to be the Officer at a place there called Mile-end,
to instruct for the doubling of files. I would do the
man what honour I can, but of this I am not certain.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: He hath out-villained villainy so far., that the rarity redeems him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A pox on him, he is a Cat still.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
His qualities being at this poor price, I need
not to ask you, if Gold will corrupt him to revolt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Sir, for a Cardecu he will sell the fee-simple of
his salvation, the inheritance of it, and cut the entail from
all remainders, and a perpetual succession for it perpetually.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What is his Brother, the other Captain Dumain?

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p: Why does he ask him of me?

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Even a Crow of the same nest: not altogether so
great as the first in goodness, but greater a great deal in
evil. He excels his Brother for a coward, yet his Brother
is reputed one of the best that is. In a retreat he outruns
any Lackey; marry in coming on, he has the
Cramp.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray
the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Aye, and the Captain of his horse, Count Rossillion.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
I will whisper with the General, and know his
pleasure.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I will no more drumming, a plague of all drums,
only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the supposition
of that lascivious young boy the Count, have I run
into this danger: yet who would have suspected an ambush
where I was taken?

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
There is no remedy sir, but you must die: the
General says, you that have so traitorously discovered
the secrets of your army, and made such pestiferous reports
of men very nobly held, can serve the world for
no honest use: therefore you must die. Come headsman,
off with his head.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O Lord sir let me live., or let me see my death.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
That shall you, and take your leave of all your
friends:
sp.l: So, look about you, know you any here?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Good morrow noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p: God bless you Captain Parolles.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p: God save you noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Lo.E.
sp.p:
Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord
Lafew? I am for France.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Good Captain will you give. me a Copy of
the sonnet you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count
Rossillion, if I were not a very Coward, I would compel
it of you, but fare you well.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
You are undone Captain all but your scarf,
that has a knot on it yet.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
If you could find out a Country where but
women were that had received so much shame, you
might begin an impudent Nation. Fare ye well sir, I
am for France too, we shall speak of you there.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great
It would burst at this: Captain I will be no more,
But I will eat, and drink, and sleep as soft
As Captain shall. Simply the thing I am
Shall make me live.: who knows himself a braggart
Let him fear this; for it will come to pass,
That every braggart shall be found an Ass.
Rust sword, cool blushes, and Parrolles live.
Safest in shame: being fooled, by foolery thrive;
There is place and means for every man alive.
I will after them.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That you may well perceive I have not wronged you,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my surety: for whose throne it is needful
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel.
Time was, I did him a desired office
Dear almost as his life, which gratitude
Through flinty Tartars bosom would peep forth,
And answer thanks. I duly am informed,
His grace is at Marcellae, to which place
We have convenient convoy: you must know
I am supposed dead, the Army breaking,
My husband hies him home, where heaven aiding,
And by the leave of my good Lord the King,
We will be before our welcome.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Gentle Madam,
You never had a servant to whose trust
Your business was more welcome.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Nor your Mistress
Ever a friend, whose thoughts more truly labour
To recompense your love: Doubt not but heaven
Hath brought me up to be your daughters dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motive
And helper to a husband. But O strange men,
That can such sweet use make of what they hate,
When saucy trusting of the cozened thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night, so lust doth play
With what it loathes, for that which is away,
But more of this hereafter: you Diana,
Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
Something in my behalf.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Let death and honesty
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Upon your will to suffer.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Yet I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on summer,
When Briars shall have leaves as well as thorns,
And be as sweet as sharpe: we must away,
Our Wagon is prepared, and time revives us,
All is well that ends well, still the fine is the Crown;
Whatever the course, the end is the renown.

div2.stage: Enter Clowne, old Lady, and Lafew.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipped
taffeta fellow there, whose villainous saffron would have
made all the unbaked and down youth of a nation in his
colour: your daughter-in-law had been alive at this
hour, and your son here at home, more advanced
by the King, than by that red-tailed humble Bee I speak
of.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I would I had not known him, it was the death
of the most virtuous gentlewoman, that ever Nature
had praise for creating. If she had partaken of my flesh
and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I could
not have owed her a more rooted love.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
It was a good Lady, it was a good Lady. We
may pick a thousand salads ere we light on such another
herb.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Indeed sir she was the sweet Marjoram of the
salad, or rather the herb of grace.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: They are not herbs you knave, they are nose-herbs.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
I am no great Nabuchadnezar sir, I have not
much skill in grace.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave
or a fool?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
A fool sir at a woman's service, and a knave at a
man's.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Your distinction.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would cozen the man of his wife, and do his
service.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: So you were a knave at his service indeed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
And I would give. his wife my bauble sir to do
her service.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave
and fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as
great a prince as you are.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Who is that, a Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Faith sir he has an English main, but his physiognomy
is more hotter in France than there.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: What prince is that?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The black prince sir, alias the prince of darkness,
alias the devil.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Hold thee there is my purse, I give. thee not this
to suggest thee from thy master thou talkest of, serve
him still.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I am a woodland fellow sir, that always loved
a great fire, and the master I speak of ever keeps a good
fire, but sure he is the Prince of the world, let his Nobility
remain in his Court. I am for the house with the
narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pomp to
enter: some that humble themselves may, but the many
will be too chill and tender, and they will be for the
flowery way that leads to the broad gate, and the great
fire.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Go thy ways, I begin to be a-weary of thee,
and I tell thee so before, because I would not fall out
with thee. Go thy ways, let my horses be well looked
to, without any tricks.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If I put any tricks upon them sir, they shall be
Jades tricks, which are their own right by the law of
Nature.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
So he is. My Lord that is gone made himself
much sport out of him, by his authority he remains
here, which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness,
and indeed he has no pace, but runs where he will.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I like him well, it is not amiss: and I was about
to tell you, since I heard of the good Ladies death, and
that my Lord your son was upon his return home. I
moved the King my master to speak in the behalf of
my daughter, which in the minority of them both, his
Majesty out of a self gracious remembrance did first
propose, his Highness hath promised me to do it, and
to stop up the displeasure he hath conceived against
your son, there is no fitter matter. How does your
Ladyship like it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
With very much content my Lord, and I wish
it happily effected.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
His Highness comes post from Marcellus, of as
able body as when he numbered thirty, he will be here
tomorrow, or I am deceived by him that in such intelligence
hath seldom failed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I
die. I have letters that my son will be here tonight:
I shall beseech your Lordship to remain with me, till
they meet together.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Madam, I was thinking with what manners I
might safely be admitted.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Lady, of that I have made a bold charter, but
I thank my God, it holds yet.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O Madam, yonder is my Lord your son with
a patch of velvet on his face, whether there be a scar under it
or no, the Velvet knows, but it is a goodly patch
of Velvet, his left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a
half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: A scar nobly got,
Or a noble scar, is a good livery of honour,
So belike is that.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: But it is your carbinado'd face.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Let us go see
your son I pray you, I long to talk
sp.l: With the young noble soldier.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
I'faith there is a dozen of them , with delicate
fine hats, and most courteous feathers, which bow the
head, and nod at every man.

div2.head: Actus Quintus.
div2.stage:
Enter Hellen, Widdow, and Diana, with
two Attendants.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But this exceeding posting day and night,
Must wear your spirits low, we cannot help it:
But since you have made the days and nights as one,
To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,
Be bold you do so grow in my requital,
As nothing can unroot you. In happy time,
This man may help me to his Majesties ear,
If he would spend his power. God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Sir, I have seen you in the Court of France.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I have been sometimes there.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I do presume sir, that you are not fallen
From the report that goes upon your goodness,
And therefore goaded with most sharpe occasions,
Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
The use of your own virtues, for the which
I shall continue thankful.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That it will please you
To give this poor petition to the King,
And aid me with that store of power you have
To come into his presence.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: The King is not here.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Not here sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Not indeed,
He hence removed last night, and with more haste
Than is his use.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Lord how we lose our pains.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: All is well that ends well yet,
Though time seem so adverse, and means unfit:
I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Marry as I take it to Rossillion,
Whither I am going.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I do beseech you sir,
Since you are like to see the King before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I presume shall render you no blame,
But rather make you thank your pains for it,
I will come after you with what good speed
Our means will make us means.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This I will do for you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
And you shall find yourself to be well thanked
whatever falls more. We must to horse again, Go, go,
provide.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Good Mr Lauatch give. my Lord Lafew this letter,
I have ere now sir been better known to you, when
I have held familiarity with fresher clothes: but I am
now sir muddied in fortunes mood, and smell somewhat
strong of her strong displeasure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly, Fortunes displeasure is but sluttish if it
smell so strongly as thou speakest of: I will henceforth
eat no Fish of Fortunes buttering. Prithee allow the
wind.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Nay you need not to stop your nose sir: I spake
but by a Metaphor.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Indeed sir, if your Metaphor stink, I will stop
my nose, or against any man's Metaphor. Prithee get thee
further.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pray you sir deliver me this paper.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Foh, prithee stand away: a paper from fortunes
close-stool, to give. to a Nobleman. Look here he
comes himself.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Here is a purr of Fortunes sir, or of Fortunes
Cat, but not a Muscat, that has fallen into the unclean
fish-pond of her displeasure, and as he says is muddied
withal. Pray you sir, use the Carp as you may, for he
looks like a poor decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally
knave. I do pity his distress in my smiles of comfort,
and leave him to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My Lord I am a man whom fortune hath cruelly
scratched.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
And what would you have me to do? It is too
late to pair her nails now. Wherein have you played
the knave with fortune that she should scratch you, who
of herself is a good Lady, and would not have knaves
thrive long under? There is a Cardecu for you: Let the
Justices make you and fortune friends; I am for other
business.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I beseech your honour to hear me one single
word,

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
you beg a single penny more: Come you shall
have it, save your word.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: My name my good Lord is Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
You beg more than word then. Cox my passion,
give. me your hand: How does your drum?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
O my good Lord, you were the first that found
me.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Was I in sooth? And I was the first that lost thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
It lies in you my Lord to bring me in some grace
for you did bring me out.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Out upon thee knave, dost thou put upon me
at once both the office of God and the devil: one brings
thee in grace, and the other brings thee out. The Kings
coming I know by his Trumpets. Sirra, inquire further
after me, I had talk of you last night, though you
are a fool and a knave, you shall eat, go to, follow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I praise God for you.

div2.stage:
Flourish. Enter King, old Lady, Lafew, the two French
Lords, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We lost a Jewel of her, and our esteem
Was made much poorer by it: but your son,
As mad in folly, lacked the sense to know
Her estimation home.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: It is past my Liege,
And I beseech your Majesty to make it
Natural rebellion, done in the blade of youth,
When oil and fire, too strong for reasons force,
Overbears it, and burns on.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My honoured Lady,
I have forgiven and forgotten all,
Though my revenges were high bent upon him,
And watched the time to shoot.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: This I must say
But first I beg my pardon: the young Lord
Did to his Majesty, his Mother, and his Lady,
Offence of mighty note; but to himself
The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife,
Whose beauty did astonish the survey
Of richest eyes: whose words all ears took captive,
Whose dear perfection, hearts that scorned to serve,
Humbly called Mistress.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Praising what is lost,
Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither,
We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill
All repetition: Let him not ask our pardon,
The nature of his great offence is dead,
And deeper than oblivion, we do bury
The incensing relics of it. Let him approach
A stranger, no offender; and inform him
So it is our will he should.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I shall my Liege.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What says he to your daughter,
Have you spoke?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: All that he is, hath reference to your Highness.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent
me, that sets him high in fame.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: He looks well on it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am not a day of season,
For thou mayst see a sun-shine, and a hail
In me at once: But to the brightest beams
Distracted clouds give. way, so stand thou forth,
The time is fair again.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My high repented blames
Dear Sovereign pardon to me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: All is whole,
Not one word more of the consumed time,
Let us take the instant by the forward top:
For we are old, and on our quickest decrees
The inaudible, and noiseless foot of time
Steals, ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this Lord?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Admiringly my Liege, at first
I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart
Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue:
Where the impression of mine eye enfixing,
Contempt his scornful Perspective did lend me,
Which warped the line, of every other favour,
Scorned a fair colour, or expressed it stolen,
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideous object. Thence it came,
That she whom all men praised, and whom myself.,
Since I have lost, have loved; was in mine eye
The dust that did offend it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Well excused:
That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away
From the great count: but love that comes too late,
Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried
To the great sender, turns a sour offence,
Crying, that is good that is gone: Our rash faults,
Make trivial price of serious things we have,
Not knowing them, until we know their grave.
Oft our displeasures to ourselves unjust,
Destroy our friends, and after weep their dust:
Our own love waking, cries to see what is done,
While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon.
Be this sweet Helens knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin,
The main consents are had, and here we will stay
To see our widowers second marriage day:
Which better than the first, O dear heaven bless,
Or, ere they meet in me, O Nature cease.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Come on my son, in whom my houses name
Must be digested: give. a favour from you
To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,
That she may quickly come. By my old beard,
And every hair that is on it, Helen that is dead
Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this,
The last that ere I took her leave at Court,
I saw upon her finger.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hers it was not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now pray you let me see it. For mine eye,
While I was speaking, oft was fastened to it:
This Ring was mine, and when I gave it Hellen,
I bad her if her fortunes ever stood
Necessitated to help, that by this token
I would relieve her. Had you that craft to reave her
Of what should stead her most?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My gracious Sovereign,
However it pleases you to take it so,
The ring was never hers.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: Son, on my life
I have seen her wear it, and she reckoned it
At her lives rate.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: I am sure I saw her wear it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You are deceived my Lord, she never saw it:
In Florence was it from a casement thrown me,
Wrapped in a paper, which contained the name
Of her that threw it: Noble she was, and thought
I stood engaged, but when I had subscribed
To mine own fortune, and informed her fully,
I could not answer in that course of Honour
As she had made the overture, she ceased
In heavy satisfaction, and would never
Receive the Ring again.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Platus himself,
That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine,
Hath not in natures mystery more science,
Than I have in this Ring. It was mine, it was Helens,
Whoever gave it you: then if you know
That you are well acquainted with yourself,
Confess it was hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her. She called the Saints to surety,
That she would never put it from her finger,
Unless she gave it to yourself in bed,
Where you have never come: or sent it us
Upon her great disaster.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: She never saw it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou speakest it falsely: as I love mine Honour,
And makest conjectural fears to come into me,
Which I would fain shut out, if it should prove
That thou art so inhumane, it will not prove so:
And yet I know not, thou didst hate her deadly,
And she is dead, which nothing but to close
Her eyes myself., could win me to believe,
More than to see this Ring. Take him away,
My fore-past proofs, however the matter fall
Shall taze my fears of little vanity,
Having vainly feared too little. Away with him,
We will sift this matter further.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If you shall prove
This Ring was ever hers, you shall as easy
Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet she never was.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am wrapped in dismal thinkings.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Gracious Sovereign.
Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not,
Here is a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for four or five removes come short,
To tender it herself. I undertook it,
Vanquished thereto by the fair grace and speech
Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know
Is here attending: her business looks in her
With an importing visage, and she told me
In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern
Your Highness with herself.

sp.p:
Upon his many protestations to marry me when his wife was
dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the Count Rossillion
a Widower, his vows are forfeited to me, and my
honours payed to him. He stole from Florence, taking no
leave, and I follow him to his Country for Justice: Grant
it me, O King, in you it best lies, otherwise a seducer flourishes
, and a poor Maid is undone
. Diana Capilet.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll
for this. I will none of him.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The heavens have thought well on thee Lafew,
To bring forth this discovery, seek these suitors:
Go speedily, and bring again the Count.
I am afeared the life of Hellen (Lady)
Was foully snatched.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: Now justice on the doers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I wonder sir, sir, wives are monsters to you,
And that you fly them as you swear them Lordship,
Yet you desire to marry. What woman is that?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I am my Lord a wretched Florentine,
Derived from the ancient Capilet,
My suite as I do understand you know,
And therefore know how far. I may be pitied.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I am her Mother sir, whose age and honour
Both suffer under this complaint we bring,
And both shall cease, without your remedy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come hither Count, do you know these Women?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Lord, I neither can nor will deny,
But that I know them, do they charge me further?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: She is none of mine my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: If you shall marry
You give. away this hand, and that is mine,
You give. away heavens vows, and those are mine:
You give. away myself., which is known mine:
For I by vow am so embodied yours,
That she which marries you, must marry me,
Either both or none.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Your reputation comes too short for my daughter,
you are no husband for her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Lord, this is a fond and desperate creature,
Whom sometime I have laughed with: Let your highness
Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour,
Than for to think that I would sink it here.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sir for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend,
Till your deeds gain them fairer: prove your honour,
Than in my thought it lies.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Good my Lord,
Ask him upon his oath, if he does think
He had not my virginity.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What sayst thou to her?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: She is impudent my Lord,
And was a common gamester to the Camp.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He does me wrong my Lord: If I were so,
He might have bought me at a common price.
Do not believe him. O behold this Ring,
Whose high respect and rich validity
Did lack a Parallel: yet for all that
He gave it to a Commoner of the Camp
If I be one.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: He blushes, and it is hit:
Of six preceding Ancestors that Gem
Conferred by testament to the sequent issue
Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife,
That Ring is a thousand proofs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Methought you said
You saw one here in Court could witness it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I did my Lord, but loath am to produce
So bad an instrument, his name is Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: I saw the man today, if man he be.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Find him, and bring him hither.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What of him:
He is quoted for a most perfidious slave
With all the spots of the world, taxed and debauched,
Whose nature sickens: but to speak a truth,
Am I, or that or this for what he will utter,
That will speak anything.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: She hath that Ring of yours.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I think she has; certain it is I liked her,
And boarded her in the wanton way of youth:
She knew her distance, and did angle for me,
Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
As all impediments in fancies course
Are motives of more fancy, and in fine,
Her insuite coming with her modern grace,
Subdued me to her rate, she got the Ring,
And I had that which any inferior might
At Market price have bought.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I must be patient:
You that have turned off a first so noble wife,
May justly diet me. I pray you yet,
(Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband)
Send for your Ring, I will return it home,
And give me mine again.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I have it not.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What Ring was yours I pray you?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Sir much like the same upon your finger.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Know you this Ring, this Ring was his of late.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And this was it I gave him being abed.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The story then goes false, you threw it him
Out of a Casement.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I have spoke the truth.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My Lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You boggle shrewdly, every feather starts you:
Is this the man you speak of?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Aye, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Tell me sirra, but tell me true I charge you,
Not fearing the displeasure of your master:
Which on your just proceeding, I will keep off,
By him and by this woman here, what know you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
So please your Majesty, my master hath been an
honourable Gentleman. Tricks he hath had in him,
which Gentlemen have.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Come, come, to the purpose: Did he love this woman?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Faith sir he did love her, but how.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How I pray you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: He did love her sir, as a Gent. loves a Woman.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: He loved her sir, and loved her not.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
As thou art a knave and no knave, what an equivocal
Companion is this?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I am a poor man, and at your Majesties command.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
He is a good drum my Lord, but a naughty
Orator.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Do you know he promised me marriage?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Faith I know more than I will speak.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: But wilt thou not speak all thou knowest?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Yes so please your Majesty: I did go between
them as I said, but more than that he loved her, for indeed
he was mad for her, and talked of Satan, and of
Limbo, and of Furies, and I know not what: yet I was in
that credit with them at that time, that I knew of their
going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her
marriage, and things which would derive me ill will to
speak of, therefore I will not speak what I know.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst
say they are married, but thou art too fine in thy evidence,
therefore stand aside. This Ring you say was yours.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Aye my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Where did you buy it? Or who gave it you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Who lent it you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: It was not lent me neither.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Where did you find it then?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I found it not.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: If it were yours by none of all these ways,
How could you give it him?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I never gave it him.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
This woman is an easy glove my Lord, she goes
off and on at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: This Ring was mine, I gave it his first wife.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: It might be yours or hers for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Take her away, I do not like her now,
To prison with her: and away with him,
Unless thou tellest me where thou hadst this Ring,
Thou diest within this hour.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I will never tell you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Take her away.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I will put in bail my liege.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I think thee now some common Customer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: By Ioue if ever I knew man it was you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wherefore hast thou accused him all this while.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Because he is guilty, and he is not guilty:
He knows I am no Maid, and he will swear to it:
I will swear I am a Maid, and he knows not.
Great King I am no strumpet, by my life,
I am either Maid, or else this old man's wife.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: She does abuse our ears, to prison with her.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Good mother fetch my bail. Stay Royal sir,
The Jeweller that owes the Ring is sent for,
And he shall surety me. But for this Lord,
Who hath abused me as he knows himself,
Though yet he never harmed me, here I quit him.
He knows himself my bed he hath defiled,
And at that time he got his wife with child:
Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick:
So there is my riddle, one that is dead is quick,
And now behold the meaning.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Is there no exorcist
Beguiles the truer Office of mine eyes?
Is it real that I see?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: No my good Lord,
It is but the shadow of a wife you see,
The name, and not the thing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Both, both, O pardon.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O my good Lord, when I was like this Maid,
I found you wondrous kind, there is your Ring,
And look you, here is your letter: this it says,
When from my finger you can get this Ring,
And is by me with child, etcetera. This is done,
Will you be mine now you are doubly won?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: If she my Liege can make me know this clearly,
I will love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If it appear not plain, and prove untrue,
Deadly divorce step between me and you.
O my dear mother do I see you living?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Mine eyes smell Onions, I shall weep anon:
Good Tom Drum lend me a handkercher.
sp.p:
So I thank thee, wait on me home, I will make sport with
thee: Let thy curtsies alone, they are scurvy ones.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let us from point to point this story know,
To make the even truth in pleasure flow:
If thou beest yet a fresh uncropped flower,
Choose thou thy husband, and I will pay thy dower.
For I can guess, that by thy honest aid,
Thou keptest a wife herself, thyself a Maid.
Of that and all the progress more and less,
Resolvedly more leisure shall express:
All yet seems well, and if it end so meet,
The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.
The King is a Beggar, now the Play is done,
All is well ended, if this suite be won,
That you express Content: which we will pay,
With strife to please you, day exceeding day:
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts,
Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
